title: Mr. Moxie Letter
body:
I just wrote a quick and dirty draft of the Moxie marketing letter that I referenced in yesterday's post. I'd like to post it here, so I can get everyone's feedback, but I don't think that would be the wisest move as many of my readers are on the mailing list for said letter. Hmmmm. What to do... what to do? Ok, here's the deal. First, see if you meet these requirements:

  1. You do not own a business in downtown Springfield.

  2. You want to read a short letter about the Moxie and leave at least one constructive comment.

  3. You have a good eye for contextual editing.

  4. You pronounce the word STRENGTH as "s•TRING•th" and not "s•TRIN•th".

  5. You have a combined annual income of at least $3.48.

If you meet these requirements, or at least meet number 1 and 2, please leave a comment on this post that says, "The sun mainly shines on the plains in Portugal... or, no. Wait a minute. Spain. The sun shines in Spain!" Don't forget to leave your e-mail address so I can send you an e-mail with the secret URL to the super secret Moxie Marketing Missive. That is all.

This post will self-destruct in 10 seconds.
author: Dan

comments.author: Stephanie
comments.body: How about the rain in Spain stays mainly in the plain?

comments.body: Hey Dan, I've got an eye for detail.  For example, I think you look best in a pale blue while Nicole should wear more peach.  And I know that it is okay to start a sentence with 'and'. (However, I do not know if I should have put the period inside the quotes).

comments.author: whittler
comments.body: Do people reaaly say "s•TRIN•th". In fact, do people really say "s•TRING•th". It's more of a "s•TRENG•th". http://www.m-w.com/ backs me on this.

comments.author: bjork24
comments.body: Yep, people say it without the "G" and it drives me bonkers. I say it "s•TRENG•th", but I spell it as "s•TRING•th" to highlight the similarity to the word STRING. You may not say it like that, but aren't you British? Thought so.

comments.author: Oz
comments.body: I am American, and I agree with Whittler.  It is not "s*TRING*th" but rather "s*STRENG*th."  But then again, I don't know what I should expect of you.  You refer to "soda" as "pop."  Sheesh, Mid-westerners....

comments.author: bjork24
comments.body: Yeah, but you're from the East coast, Oz... you might as well be British. Do you really say strength with two S's? Look to the PECO buiding!

comments.body: Wait, *I'm* from the East coast, and I say 'pop, too!  That argument's no good.
